w:r.w:t: Worth 40% of the total marks for the unit.
Relevant Objectives from the Unit Outline
Apply different test case design techniques, recognising the strength and weakness of each and being able to choose techniques appropriately
Examine a suite of test cases in terms of test adequacy coverage
Implement a case study, demonstrating appropriate use of testing techniques and generate the test harnesses for the software system.

This issue will be dealt with on a case-by case basis as to whether a penalty will be imposed. In certain circumstances, it may be possible for two teams that have lost team members to merge as one.
Submit the contact details of your team to the tutor by the end of Week
If you decide to leave your team, or you are voted off the team, please consider the following:
The team member leaving may lose 10% of the awarded marks for this assignment;
A team that removes a member may lose 5% of the awarded marks for this assignment; and
A team that recruits a student allocated to another team may lose 10% of the awarded marks for this assignment.

You have just been hired as a software tester by a software company. You are asked to carry out software testing of a prototype system that the company has contracted a group of students to develop. Source code and limited amount of documentation associated with this software is available
. Using the source code and the documentation provided for this initial prototype, the team leader for testing has asked your team to implement the testing of the system using
pytest and other associated testing libraries that may help

In the section of your report for your testing approach, it should include a description of what steps you have undertaken (so that someone can repeat your approach by following the steps that you have outlined) and what testing techniques you have employed together with relevant artefacts (e.g. control flow graph in the case of whitebox testing or equivalence classes in the case of black-box testing). Do not leave the compilation of minutes to the end of the projectâ€”it is an on-going activity. This deliverable is marked on a pass/fail basis, with a fail resulting in the loss of up to two (2) marks. Record your minutes following the template provided in Appendix 1. It would be expected that a team would meet weekly to discuss progress. Note that each item on the action list must have a unique identifier across the life of the project.

Each member of the team is expected to develop test cases associated with one or more functionality of the software system by applying appropriate testing techniques (for example, black-box: equivalence partitioning, boundary value analysis; white-box: control-flow, data-flow). The test suite should be as complete as possible for testing your system. On each of the submitted suite of testcases, the name of the team member responsible for its creation should be clearly visible

Peer assessment is an important part of the group learning process in terms of group dynamics, equity and fairness. You need to objectively evaluate the contribution of each of your colleagues (and yourself) to your group project.
When your project is due, enter your name and the names of the other members of your team at the top of the table below.

For each item, enter the appropriate number (0-5) for each individual (including yourself, which is a self-assessment): 0 = no participation, 1 = little participation, 2 = some participation, 3 = adequate participation, 4 = active participation, 5 = outstanding participation.
When complete, email this form to your lecturer
the assignment due date. Failure to email this form may result in your entire team not receiving a mark for the project component of the unit.

Comments (if you give any team member a mark of zero (0), one (1) or five (5), you must provide a quantifiable comment for each mark):
-based prototype component is a booking system with 6 high-level functions.
The Meeting Scheduling System is a

-based application designed to manage and facilitate various scheduling tasks within an organisation. Its primary functionalities include scheduling meetings, booking vacations, checking room and employee availability, and viewing agendas. This specification focuses on user inputs and their interaction with the system.
Each corresponding to a different choice
Room: (String) â€“ list of valid rooms
Person: (String) â€“ list of valid people
Please note that some options can be provided â€œcancelâ€ or â€˜allâ€, but this was not captured in the document.
Allows users to schedule meetings by providing specific details.
Input: Month (Int) between 1 â€“ 12, day (int) between 1 â€“ 31, start hour (int) between 0 - 23, end hour (int) between 0 - 23, room (string), person (string), description (string).
Enables booking of vacation periods for employees.
Input: Start month (Int) between 1 â€“ 12, start day (int) between 1 â€“ 31, end month (Int) between 1 â€“ 12, end day (int) between 1 â€“ 31, person (string).
Function to check if a room is available at a given time.
Input: Month (Int) between 1 â€“ 12, day (int) between 1 â€“ 31, start hour (int) between 0 - 23, end hour (int) between 0 â€“ 23.
Allows checking if a person is available for a meeting.
Input: Month (Int) between 1 â€“ 12, day (int) between 1 â€“ 31, start hour (int) between 0 - 23, end hour (int) between 0 â€“ 23.
Users can view the schedule of a room.
Input: Month (Int) between 1 â€“ 12, day (int or string) between 1 â€“ 31/ â€œallâ€, room (string).
Input: Month (Int) between 1 â€“ 12, day (int or string) between 1 â€“ 31/ â€œallâ€, person (string).
The system is operated through CLI, where users enter commands and data in response to prompts.
Users must follow the prompts on the CLI.
For names and descriptions, case sensitivity should be properly handled.
For options selection etc., inputs should be numeric, handled as integers.
The system should validate dates, especially considering leap years and month-specific days (e.g., 29/02, 30/11).
Special attention is required for handling edge cases like booking events between 11:00 PM and 11:59 PM.
The system should prevent illogical vacation bookings, such as a start date on the 32nd day of a month.
Clear and informative error messages should be displayed for invalid inputs.
On successful input, the system should provide appropriate confirmation messages.

This information was not correctly documented during the requirements gathering and planning stages, output has not been correctly collated. Output exists, but its hardcoded in the software and needs to be discovered.

Other functionality will provide relevant output to console, of which was not stated in the requirements specification/ nor provided by the users. For these messages, please use the program to find the appropriate outputs.
